The **[Milwaukee Brewers](/wiki/Milwaukee_Brewers "Milwaukee Brewers")' 1998
season** was the first season for the franchise as a member of the [National
League](/wiki/National_League "National League"). The Brewers finished in
fifth in the [NL Central](/wiki/National_League_Central "National League
Central"), 28 games behind the [Houston Astros](/wiki/Houston_Astros "Houston
Astros"), with a record of 74 wins and 88 losses. Before the 1998 regular
season began, two new teams—the [Arizona
Diamondbacks](/wiki/Arizona_Diamondbacks "Arizona Diamondbacks") and [Tampa
Bay Devil Rays](/wiki/Tampa_Bay_Devil_Rays "Tampa Bay Devil Rays")—were added
by Major League Baseball. This resulted in the American League and National
League having fifteen teams. However, in order for MLB officials to continue
primarily intraleague play, both leagues would need to carry a number of teams
that was divisible by two, so the decision was made to move one club from the
AL Central to the NL Central.

This realignment was widely considered to have great financial benefit to the
club moving. However, to avoid the appearance of a conflict of interest,
Commissioner (then club owner) Bud Selig decided another team should have the
first chance to switch leagues. The choice was offered to the Kansas City
Royals, who ultimately decided to stay in the American League.[1] The choice
then fell to the Brewers, who, on November 6, 1997, elected to move to the
National League. Had the Brewers elected not to move to the National League,
the Minnesota Twins would have been offered the opportunity to switch
leagues.[2]

Also, Milwaukee was not totally unfamiliar with the National League, having
been the home of the NL [Braves](/wiki/Atlanta_Braves "Atlanta Braves") for 13
seasons (1953–1965).

##
Offseason[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1998_Milwaukee_Brewers_season&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Offseason")]

  * December 1, 1997: [Jack Voigt](/wiki/Jack_Voigt "Jack Voigt") was released by the Brewers.[3]
  * December 8, 1997: [Mike Fetters](/wiki/Mike_Fetters "Mike Fetters"), [Ben McDonald](/wiki/Ben_McDonald "Ben McDonald"), and [Ron Villone](/wiki/Ron_Villone "Ron Villone") were traded by the Brewers to the [Cleveland Indians](/wiki/Cleveland_Indians "Cleveland Indians") for [Marquis Grissom](/wiki/Marquis_Grissom "Marquis Grissom") and [Jeff Juden](/wiki/Jeff_Juden "Jeff Juden").[4]
  * January 14, 1998: [Bob Hamelin](/wiki/Bob_Hamelin "Bob Hamelin") was signed as a free agent by the Brewers.[5]
  * March 11, 1998: [Mark Watson](/wiki/Mark_Watson_\(baseball\) "Mark Watson \(baseball\)") was traded by the Brewers to the Cleveland Indians for Ben McDonald.[6]

### Notable
transactions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=1998_Milwaukee_Brewers_season&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Notable transactions")]

  * June 2, 1998: [J. J. Putz](/wiki/J._J._Putz "J. J. Putz") was drafted by the Brewers in the 17th round of the [1998 Major League Baseball draft](/wiki/1998_Major_League_Baseball_draft "1998 Major League Baseball draft"), but did not sign.[7]
  * June 24, 1998: Dave Weathers was selected off waivers by the Milwaukee Brewers from the Cincinnati Reds.[8]
  * July 23, 1998: [Doug Jones](/wiki/Doug_Jones_\(baseball\) "Doug Jones \(baseball\)") was traded by the Brewers to the Cleveland Indians for [Eric Plunk](/wiki/Eric_Plunk "Eric Plunk").[9]
  * July 31, 1998: [Mike Kinkade](/wiki/Mike_Kinkade "Mike Kinkade") was traded by the Brewers to the [New York Mets](/wiki/New_York_Mets "New York Mets") for [Bill Pulsipher](/wiki/Bill_Pulsipher "Bill Pulsipher").[10]
  * August 7, 1998: [Jeff Juden](/wiki/Jeff_Juden "Jeff Juden") was selected off waivers from the Brewers by the [Anaheim Angels](/wiki/Anaheim_Angels "Anaheim Angels").[11]
